title: The impact of the 2007 Legal Services Act on organisational form, the legal profession, and future skills requirements.
abstractText:
Despite the significance of the legal services sector, there is limited understanding of the inter-play between changing market conditions and the governance, leadership in sector organisations.

The research project will address gaps in current research and, in so doing, contribute to the relatively new research agenda (Muzio and Kirkpatrick, 2011) concerning the interface and evolving relationship between governance, management structures and professional occupations.

The research will undertake the first empirical exploration of the development in organisational structure in the sector since the 2007 Legal Services Act (LSA), focusing on the creation of Alternative Business Structures (ABS) type organisations and associated innovations in governance and management. Using a combination of documentary analysis, a survey of law firms and semi-structured interviews with sample of them, the research will explore:

  • Market strategies and the challenges faced in moving to or maintaining business strategies in the light of new regulation
  • The implications of these strategies for new organisational forms
  • Implications for the professional skills of lawyers and, in particular, changes in the supply of, and demand for, skills in management occupations required to engage with and operate in the new environment
